Repeat this story with no changes whatsoever: There was once a cat by the name of Thomas. This was no ordinary cat, however. Thomas was special. Not only was he wise beyond his years, but he also had the power to speak English. Born as a stray on the mean streets of London, the fight for survival was constant: running away from wild seagulls and competing for scraps outside the myriad fish and chip shops of Camden Market. Life for Thomas was dismal, until he met a barkeep named Roland. In the hustle and bustle of the markets, no one had noticed Thomas at all, let alone his conversational talents, until one fateful night.
After closing Heorot Brewhaus, Roland encountered Thomas while leaving the pub, nearly tripping over the poor kitten. Tired and frustrated after a long shift, Roland exclaimed without restraint, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” Immediately, Roland heard a meek, “I’m sorry.”
“Oh, no worries,” Roland replied, assuming he was addressing some imagined drunkard in the darkness, embarrassed by his outburst. “It's just all these damn strays,” he continued.
“That’s rude. I am right here in front of you,” said Thomas clearly.
Roland looked around and realized he was alone, at least alone from other humans. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me. I've had a long day at the pub, and I don’t need any more problems!” In a mixture of fear and frustration, Roland looked down at the sidewalk and saw something his eyes could barely believe, a stray kitten saying, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.”
After the initial shock wore off, Roland had a brilliant idea. He would offer Thomas a job at the bar, the first bar in all of London with a talking cat. No, the world! That was sure to bring in the extra customers his boss had been worrying about. Thomas gladly accepted. He was no longer a stray, as Heorot Brewhaus quickly became his home.
Many years passed, filled with days and nights of Thomas talking to various patrons, offering great advice and engaging conversation. Roland poured countless ales and Guinnesses, carefully cleaning every night after close, making sure the bar remained hospitable for Thomas and the customers. Heorot Brewhaus experienced unimaginable success. As word spread about Thomas, more and more people visited just to see the talking cat, often buying drinks while enveloped in deep discussions about the political and economic state of the world.
Thomas lived a great life. At the age of 18, he succumbed to his greatest weakness, working too hard. Thomas’s soul began a long and arduous journey up the stairway to heaven. Meanwhile, Heorot Brewhaus descended into chaos. Roland was overwhelmed with grief. He had gone from laboring each night for menial pay, wondering if the bar would even remain open the following month, to becoming a mainstay at one of London's greatest institutions, complete with a 401(k) and work-life balance. It turned out Thomas wasn’t the only one saved from scraps and seagulls on that fateful night when their paths crossed. Most importantly, Thomas had become a friend, and his loss weighed heavily on Roland.
The owner of Heorot Brewhaus had other concerns. Having just lost their most important employee, how could they continue to overcharge tourists for pints of domestic beer without a talking cat? Desperate for a solution, the owner came up with an idea. Taxidermying a cat might seem a bit odd, and the owner realized this, but he was desperate to retain the traffic and notoriety Thomas had brought the establishment. They decided on a compromise, not taxidermying all of Thomas, just his tail.
A week passed, and Thomas’s tail was mounted behind the bar. Roland found this distasteful at best but kept his opinion to himself. That night, a celebration of life was held for Thomas. People from across the globe came to mourn the passing of the talking cat, sharing stories of Thomas and the positive impact he had made.
Thomas finally arrived at the gates of heaven, guarded by Saint Peter. Thomas asked Peter for permission to enter, citing his innumerable great deeds and the help he'd offered through countless conversations. Peter agreed with Thomas but explained, “Unfortunately, I cannot allow you to pass through these gates, Thomas. You have lived a great life filled to the brim with virtue and Guinness, but heaven does not accept a fractured soul, no matter the piety of its pieces.” Thomas was upset but determined. He would descend back to Earth to retrieve the missing part of his soul, the tail hanging as a trophy at Heorot Brewhaus.
The funeral had been a lively event. Just as on the night the two friends had met, Roland found himself closing the bar alone. As the last glasses were washed and the tables cleaned, something remarkable happened. The door burst open with force, and a familiar voice filled the room: “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.”
Roland smiled faintly and shook his head, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

Ah, let me begin the tale of a remarkable feline known as Thomas. But mind you, this recounting may flourish with some embellishments, for every retelling breathes fresh air into the old bones of a story.

Once upon a time, in the bustling heart of London, lived a cat named Thomas. Ah, but he was not just any cat! No, dear listeners, Thomas was extraordinary. He possessed wisdom that belied his tender years and, even more remarkably, he could speak the English tongue. A stray born on the tough streets of the city, he fought daily for his survival, dodging feral seagulls and scrounging for morsels outside the myriad of fish-and-chip shops that peppered Camden Market.

Life, I must tell you, was grim for Thomas—until the fated night he crossed paths with a barkeep named Roland. Amid the clamor of the market, where no one noticed the clever little stray, fate had another plan. 

After a long, wearisome shift at Heorot Brewhaus, Roland, in his fatigued state, stumbled upon Thomas, nearly tripping over the unsuspecting kitten. With exasperation boiling over, Roland shouted into the night, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” But what happened next took him by surprise—a soft voice replied, “I’m sorry.”

At first, Roland figured he was merely responding to a ghostly drunkard lost in the shadows. “No worries,” he returned, both confused and annoyed. “It's just those pesky strays…” 

Yet, Thomas interjected with clarity, “That’s rude. I am right here in front of you.” Roland, astonished, looked about for anyone else, but alas, it was only him and this audacious kitten. “Where are you hiding?! Quit messing with me! I can’t take any more surprises!” 

Then, gazing down at the sidewalk, Roland saw the cat with his own eyes. “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy,” Thomas chided gently. 

Once the shock melted away, inspiration struck Roland like a bolt from the blue! A job offer materialized in his mind: a talking cat at his bar, a novelty sure to spark curiosity and draw in patrons like moths to a flame! Thomas, eager to escape the life of a stray, joyfully accepted this unique opportunity, finding a home in the warm embrace of Heorot Brewhaus.

Years rolled on, with Thomas sharing wisdom and clever tidbits with patrons seeking advice and a hearty drink. Meanwhile, Roland poured countless ales, scrubbed the bar to perfection, and ensured a delightful atmosphere for the talking cat and its growing clientele. Heorot Brewhaus saw splendid success, renowned far and wide as the pub with the extraordinary Thomas. 

As word spread of the feline philosopher, guests flocked to hear his musings on matters both trivial and profound. Yet, alas! Time is a thief, and at age 18, Thomas was claimed by his tireless heart that had worked through too many nights. His spirit began its slow ascent to the heaven beyond.

Roland, stricken with grief, found himself drowning in memories of their shared triumphs and laughter. Once a struggling barkeep, he had transformed the bar into a beloved establishment, where camaraderie flourished thanks to his beloved friend. But now, the absence of Thomas weighed heavily on his heart—a dear soul whose friendship had blossomed amidst chaos.

Yet even in grief, the pragmatic owner of Heorot Brewhaus faced a dilemma: Without their prized talking cat, how could they continue to lure tourists and sell overpriced pints? In a moment of desperation, an unconventional idea stirred—the spirit of Thomas could live on, so long as part of him remained in the bar. They chose to preserve his tail as a tribute, mounding it against the bar, though Roland found the idea distasteful.

Time passed, and a celebration of life for Thomas drew people together, their hearts brimming with fondness for the feline sage. Thomas, meanwhile, faced a test of his worth at the gates of heaven, where Saint Peter stood firm. “You cannot enter,” Peter explained with sympathy, “for a fractured soul cannot pass through, though you’ve lived a noble life.”

Determined to reclaim what was lost, Thomas made the journey back to Earth to retrieve his tail, the fragment of his soul. 

It was a familiar scene unfolding once more, as Roland found himself alone at the bar, cleaning up after the moving funeral held in Thomas’s honor. Suddenly, the door flung open with vigor, and there was that unmistakable voice: “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.”

A faint smile crept upon Roland’s lips, and with a playful shake of his head, he replied, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

And thus, dear friends, the tale spins onwards, with laughter mingling with sorrow and lessons of friendship etched forever in the heart of Heorot Brewhaus.

Seizing his moment of inspiration, Roland proposed a novel idea—a job for Thomas at the bar! Imagine the first establishment in all of London (no, the whole world!) with a talking cat. Thomas, relieved to be rescued from his stray existence, happily accepted, and thus began his new life at Heorot Brewhaus.

Seasons changed into years, and Thomas thrived, weaving tales and wisdom into the hearts of patrons who sought him out for a sprinkle of advice and a dash of conversation, all while Roland kept the ales flowing. Their partnership flourished, turning the bar into a haven renowned for its enchanting feline and the camaraderie of spirited discussions that enveloped the air.

Time, as it is wont to do, marched on. All too desperate to preserve Thomas's legacy, they chose a rather macabre route—taxidermying Thomas’s tail as a keepsake. Ah, what a strange twist of fate! Roland chuckled softly and replied, shaking his head, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

And so, dear friends, the tale of Thomas the cat persists, a tapestry woven with threads of friendship, loss, and the undying spirit of loyalty. It teaches us that even in absence, the bonds we form echo eternally, reminding us to cherish those we hold dear in our hearts.
